awd_titl_txt: IGE: Developing a Research Engineer Identity
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) award to North Carolina A&T State University (NCAT) will study the development of research identity in engineering graduate students. Briefly stated, research identity refers to the ways in which graduate students define themselves as researchers and is an important factor in student success. Specifically, this project will implement and test approaches to foster research identity development for graduate students in non-research-intensive institutions. It should be noted that smaller institutions/programs often face deficiencies that can impact the ability of faculty mentors to foster student research identities both individually and as part of a larger group. In engineering, a faculty advisor generally guides the graduate research experience and the advisor is the primary resource to help graduate students develop their identities as engineering researchers.  Given this apprenticeship model, the mentoring and guidance that a student receives in developing a professional identity is largely dependent on the style, resources, and graduate student group size of the faculty mentor.  This project is testing interventions that could potentially overcome these limitations, particularly for students in smaller graduate programs.

This study on engineering research identity will be conducted at a Carnegie R2 institution (NCAT), a leading producer of African-American engineers, and it will implement a three-pronged approach that is grounded in sociological and psychological theories of identity.   The project entails (1) establishing a Research Engineer Network that will help graduate students develop a research engineer identity; (2) forming Small Research Groups of faculty members with common interests who will foster students' research skills; and (3) designing and administering a survey-based Research Engineer Identity scale and assessment using a mixed-methods research design that includes focus groups, structured interviews, and web-based surveys. The design will culminate with a quasi-experimental test comparing the development of research identify among students participating in the study and a control group of matched students. The three coordinated innovations in this project will collectively build and assess an innovative infrastructure for developing research identify in graduate engineering students. It is anticipated that the project results will be applicable to universities broadly, while particularly informing practice in smaller graduate programs.

The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education. The goals of IGE are to pilot, test and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University

por.por_cntn:
In this National Science Foundation Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) project, a team of sociologists, engineering faculty, researchers, and administrators at North Carolina A&T State University have been building a graduate learning environment that promotes the development and assessment of students' research identity (RI). A Research Identity (RI) includes personal, role, and group-based defining oneself as someone who "solves problems by rearranging the stuff of the world to make new things." Specifically, this project has implemented and tested approaches to foster research identity development for graduate students in non-research-intensive institutions. We have fostered a mentorship model wherein; the student receives mentoring and guidance in developing a professional identity to broaden their research and professional competencies.

Intellectual Merit: The IGE project includes three coordinated initiatives. First, the Graduate Researcher Identity Development (GRID) program was developed that provides research-intensive degree-seeking students in STEM disciplines with knowledge and a skill set that will enhance their graduate researcher experience. The course introduces students to the concept of "Graduate Researcher Identity" and a set of academic, professional, and personal skills that foster the development of GRID. The course includes a series of asynchronous, self-paced modules and in-person events focused on networking, mentoring, and career preparation. Second, the IGE project supports the development of Small Research Groups (SRGs) in which two or more faculty and graduate students collaborate on a research or creative product. Finally, the IGE project engages in a Research Identity (RI) Assessment Process that involves pairing well-established social and psychological theories of identity with a mixed-method social science research design to identify the content, character, and complications associated with efforts to develop RI among graduate students.

Broader Impact: The core components of the three coordinated initiatives for developing research identify in graduate engineering students has been developed. A mentorship program is established with academic, industry and research organizations for graduate students to explore a variety of career pathways and collaborations with external partners under expert guidance. The research identity project has been adopted by other graduate disciplines at NC A&T beyond engineering, while particularly informing practice in smaller graduate programs. The GRID program is also extended to the undergraduate researchers via the NC-LSAMP program on campus. The results of this project have been disseminated via conference proceedings, presentations, panel discussions, manuscripts, and a web-portal. This project has validated interventions to graduate education and generated the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2023
Modified by: Salil Desai
